Question 1: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1 is also called as  
 .
questions.explanation: MEN1 is also referred to as Wermer's syndrome.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following conditions is not observed in MEN1 syndrome?
questions.explanation: Anterior pituitary tumours are associated with MEN1 syndrome, not posterior pituitary tumors.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 35-year-old man presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea. He had a history of 
hyperparathyroidism and a transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection. Which of the following is 
the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome and gastrinoma is the most common 
functional enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 / Wermer's syndrome. Enteropancreatic tumors in MEN1 syndrome are: • Non-functioning pancreatic tumors (most common overall) • Functioning pancreatic tumors : • Gastrinoma - 50% (most common among functioning pancreatic tumours) • Insulinoma - 30% • Glucagonoma • VIPoma (least common)

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the first and second part of duodenum. MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic 
islets, and anterior pituitary. Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome and if it is associated 
with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcers, the condition is called Zollinger 
Ellison syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of recurrent episodes of weakness, 
headache, sweating, and fainting after fasting. He tells that the symptoms improve after the 
consumption of food. There is a history of MEN1 syndrome running in the family. Serum C 
peptide levels are found to be elevated. What is the definitive treatment of choice in this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
129 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario along with elevated serum C peptide levels points towards a diagnosis 
of insulinoma in a MEN1 patient. The definitive treatment of choice in this patient is surgery. Insulinoma is the second most common functioning enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 syndrome. 
Investigation of choice is 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels. These parameters are 
measured when the patient develops hypoglycemic symptoms during a supervised 72-hour fasting 
period. The treatment of choice is surgery, ranging from enucleation of a single tumor to pancreatectomy. Non-surgical management of insulinoma includes frequent consumption of carbohydrate-rich 
meals, octreotide or diazoxide, which are not always successful. Selpercatinib, a kinase inhibitor was recently approved by the FDA. It is used to treat tumours 
with a mutation in the RET gene. These are non-small cell lung cancer, medullary thyroid cancer, 
and other types of thyroid cancers in patients with a mutation in the RET gene.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following is the most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 
syndrome?
questions.explanation: The most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 syndrome is angiofibroma. Cutaneous tumors in MEN1 Syndrome are: • Angiofibroma – 85% • Collagenoma – 70% • Lipoma - 33%

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common component of Sipple’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The most common component of MEN2A syndrome, which is also called Sipple’s syndrome is 
medullary thyroid cancer.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Pituitary adenoma is not a characteristic feature of the symptom complex of MEN2 and its 
variants, but it is observed in MEN1 and MEN4 syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2B 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Meningioma is not commonly seen in MEN2B Syndrome. MEN1 syndrome is associated with 
meningiomas.

questions.question: Question 11: MEN4 syndrome is caused by a mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.explanation:
MEN4 is caused by genetic mutations in CDKN1B (cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor), located on 
chromosome 12. MEN1 is caused due to MEN1 gene mutation on chromosome 11. MEN2 is associated with RET proto-oncogene mutation on chromosome 10.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following malignancies would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN4 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma is not associated with MEN4 syndrome, but it is associated with 
MEN2 syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient presented with abdominal pain and swelling in his scrotum and was diagnosed to 
have testicular carcinoma. There is a history of MEN syndrome running in his family. Which 
of the following conditions is he likely to have?
questions.explanation:
This patient is likely to have MEN4 syndrome as reproductive organ tumors are a characteristic 
feature of this condition. 131
